content.introduction:
Great job on your first program – now let's understand *why* Python code looks so clean and readable! Building on your setup, this lesson dives into Python's syntax rules, like how spaces (indentation) act as invisible fences for code groups. This matters because Python enforces readability; messy code simply won't run, training you to write professional code from day one.

Imagine recipes where ingredients are bulleted perfectly – Python's rules make your programs that organized. Mastering this unlocks writing multi-line code confidently, without syntax errors frustrating you.
lesson_overview: Python's core syntax: no semicolons, newline-based statements
The power of indentation for blocks (loops, functions later)
Comments for notes that Python ignores
What you'll be able to do: Write error-free multi-line Python scripts

core_concepts.title: Statements and Newlines
core_concepts.explanation:
A statement is one complete instruction, like 'print('Hi')'. Python ends statements with newlines, not semicolons (unlike JavaScript). You can put multiple on one line with ';', but don't – readability first.[5]

Why? English sentences end with periods; Python uses line breaks for clarity. No need to count braces. This simplicity speeds learning.

Analogy: Like writing a shopping list – each item on its line, no extra symbols cluttering.
core_concepts.code_example:
print('Line 1')
print('Line 2')
# Two statements, two lines.

core_concepts.title: Indentation: Python's Block Structure
core_concepts.explanation:
Indentation (4 spaces or 1 tab) defines code blocks, like what's inside a loop. Wrong spaces? Error![5][3]

Why vital? Visual grouping – indented code 'belongs' to the line above. Builds habit of organized thinking.

Example: Future if-statement indents its body. Consistent 4 spaces standard.

core_concepts.title: Comments with #
core_concepts.explanation:
Comments start with #; Python ignores to end of line. Use for notes.[3]

Why? Explains *why* code exists, not what (obvious). Great for beginners documenting thoughts.
core_concepts.code_example:
# This is a comment
print('Code runs')  # Inline comment

guided_walkthrough: Step 1: Write a single statement: print('Syntax test'). Run – works? Newline ends it.
Step 2: Add comment above: # My first syntax. Run – ignored, code same. Shows notes don't break.
Step 3: Create indented block: if True: print('Inside'). Use exactly 4 spaces. Run – prints. Change to 2 spaces? Error! Why: Python strict on consistency.

Step 4: Multi-line: print('Start')
if 1 == 1:
    print('True block')
print('End'). Run – shows block structure.
Step 5: Check editor settings for 4-space tabs. Verify: Run in REPL line-by-line, watch IndentationError.

practical_examples.code:
# Program to greet user
print('Welcome to Python!')
print('Syntax is simple.')

# Section 2
greeting = 'Hello again'
print(greeting)
practical_examples.explanation: Comments divide sections. Each print is newline-ended statement. Introduces variables gently (stores data). Readable like a story.

practical_examples.code:
is_learning = True
if is_learning:
    print('Keep going!')
    print('You got this.')  # Same indent level
print('Outside if')
practical_examples.explanation: if checks condition; indented prints run only if True. Both prints same indent (same block). Outside not. Teaches block logic early.

common_pitfalls: Mistake 1: Mixing tabs and spaces for indent. Why? Python sees different whitespace. Fix: Editor 'show whitespace', use spaces only.
Mistake 2: No indent after colon (:). Why? Python expects block. Fix: Always 4 spaces post-colon.
Mistake 3: Comments in wrong place breaking strings. Why? # inside quotes treated as code. Fix: # only outside strings.
content.mental_model: Python syntax is like a poem: each line a complete thought (statement), stanzas defined by indents (blocks), footnotes (# comments). Messy poem doesn't flow; clean code runs smoothly.
content.summary: Python's newline statements, strict indentation for blocks, and # comments create readable code you now understand deeply. These rules – no semicolons, 4-space indents – prevent errors and build pro habits. Connected to prior lesson: Your Hello World now scales to complex scripts.
further_thinking: How does Python indentation compare to brace-languages like C++; why might Python's way reduce bugs?
Rewrite a messy indented code snippet using consistent 4 spaces – what changes?
Create a 10-line program with comments, prints, and one if-block telling a short story.

quiz.question: What ends a Python statement?
quiz.explanation: Python uses natural line breaks for statements, promoting readability unlike semicolon-heavy languages.

quiz.question: What happens if you use 2 spaces instead of 4 for indentation?
quiz.explanation: Python requires consistent indentation (convention: 4 spaces); mixing levels breaks block detection.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of # in Python?
quiz.explanation: # tells Python to ignore rest of line, used for human-readable explanations.

content.introduction:
Nice work on your first program! Now let's learn why Python code looks so neat and easy to read. Python uses spaces (called indentation) to group code together, like invisible boxes around related lines. This helps you write clear code that always works.

Think of it like organizing your desk: everything in its place makes it easy to find. Learning this now means you can write longer programs without getting stuck on errors.
lesson_overview: How Python uses new lines to end simple instructions
How spaces group code into blocks
How to add notes with # that Python ignores
What you'll do: Write simple multi-line code that runs perfectly

core_concepts.title: Statements End with New Lines
core_concepts.explanation:
A statement is one simple instruction, like print('Hi'). In Python, each statement goes on its own line. The new line acts like a period at the end of a sentence.[5]

Why? It makes code easy to read, like a list where each item is on a new line. No need for extra symbols like semicolons.

Example: Two print statements, each on its own line.

core_concepts.title: Indentation Groups Code
core_concepts.explanation:
Indentation means adding spaces at the start of a line. Use exactly 4 spaces to show code belongs together, like inside a box.[1][2][5]

Why? It shows which lines go together. Python checks this carefully - wrong spaces mean an error.

Always use 4 spaces, never tabs. Keep the same number of spaces for lines in the same group.

core_concepts.title: Comments Start with #
core_concepts.explanation:
Use # to write notes. Python ignores everything after # until the end of the line.[3][5]

Why? Notes help you remember what your code does. Good for explaining your ideas.

Put # at the start of a line or after code on the same line.
core_concepts.code_example:
# This is a note
print('Hello')  # This is also a note

guided_walkthrough:
Step 1: Type this and run it:
print('Test 1')
print('Test 2')
See? Each line is one instruction. New line ends it.

Step 2: Add a note above:
# My test program
print('Test')
Run it. The note doesn't run - Python skips it.

Step 3: Try indentation. Type:
if True:
    print('Yes!')
The print line has 4 spaces. Run it - works! Now change to 2 spaces. Error!

Step 4: Put it together:
print('Start')
if True:
    print('Middle')
print('End')
Run it. See how spaces group the middle line?
Step 5: Check your editor shows spaces. Practice typing 4 spaces after : (colon).

practical_examples.code:
# Greeting program
print('Hi there')
print('Nice to meet you')
practical_examples.explanation: Each print is one line. The # note explains what it does. Easy to read like a short story.

practical_examples.code:
rain = True
if rain:
    print('Stay inside')
print('Check weather')
practical_examples.explanation: The if line ends with :. Next line has 4 spaces - it runs because rain is True. Last line has no spaces - always runs.

common_pitfalls: Problem 1: Using tabs instead of spaces. Fix: Use only spaces (4 per level). Check editor settings.
Problem 2: Forgetting spaces after :. Fix: Always add 4 spaces after every :.
Problem 3: Wrong number of spaces (2 or 5). Fix: Count to 4 every time in a block.
Problem 4: # inside quotes. Fix: # only works outside quotes: print('No # here') works, but print('#') is code.
content.mental_model: Think of Python code like a shopping list with sections. Each item is one line. Sections use spaces to show what's grouped together. Notes with # are like sticky notes that don't get checked off.
content.summary: You now know Python ends lines with new lines, uses 4 spaces for groups, and # for notes. Practice these and your code will always look clean and work right.
further_thinking: Why does Python use spaces instead of {} braces?
Write print('A') with a # note above it.
Make an if True: with one indented print().

quiz.question: What ends a Python statement?
quiz.explanation: Python uses the end of each line, like the end of a sentence.

quiz.question: How many spaces for indentation?
quiz.explanation: Use 4 spaces every time. Same number in each group.

quiz.question: What does # do?
quiz.explanation: # tells Python to skip the rest of the line.
